profileAlternative.name: Christopher Haskell
profileAlternative.headline: Vice President and Head, West Coast Innovation Center at Bayer
profileAlternative.summary:
Business development professional with a focus on developing partnered research programs between Bayer’s global research activities and early programs in academia and biotech. My focus is on developing innovative business and collaboration models that drive the project to clear decision points based on solid science.

Currently expanding the CoLaborator life science incubator at Bayer's West Coast Innovation Center in Mission Bay, San Francisco.

Specialties: • Over ten years in drug development, including programs in small molecule compounds and biologics. Experience in both early research as well as clinical development programs
• Disease biology background in Autoimmune disorders, Oncology, Neurology and Cardiovascular with in depth knowledge of cellular immunology and GPCR drug development

positions.title: Bayer
positions.description:
The Science Hub supports Bayer’s Global Drug Discovery through developing and managing partnerships with US academic research institutions and startup biotechnology companies. This group participates in all aspects of the partnering process, including: scouting for opportunities, shaping the partnered project, contract work, as well as Alliance Management of the ongoing collaborations.

The Science Hub also developed and runs the CoLaborator, a biotech incubator space that opened in the fall of 2012 in Mission Bay, San Francisco. The CoLaborator houses a number of startup life science firms, and has been developed as a vehicle to foster collaboration between Bayer and these emerging innovators.
http://www.colaborator.bayer.com

given.text:
Chris is an excellent scientist with a rare ability to bring teams together and get the best results out of a group. I've worked with Chris in several projects where he was the project team leader; his projects were always on time, with well defined goals and the best scientific team available. Chris is able to motivate people to work in his project based on his enthusiasms for his projects, his scientific knowledge and his people skills. It was always a pleasure working with him and I recommend Chris to any organization wanting to build excellent scientific teams.
…
See more

I have known Chris Haskell for over 6 years both as a colleague and as a valued member of my department. Chris and I share major research interests in GPCRs both their role in pathophysiology and their utility as drug targets. Chris has always impressed me as a highly intelligent and thoughtful scientist who has an incredibly broad range of knowledge. His insights into disease process and his interdisciplinary knowledge make him an excellent scientist. His knowledge is not only theoretical; he has very practical hands-on laboratory skills that he has applied to many immunology projects, both as Team Leader and as member. At Berlex Chris has served on various committees for example the Scientific Advisory Committee where he consistently makes valuable contributions and suggestions. In addition he has chaired various working groups and has been a group leader on a number of very challenging projects all of which have benefited from his scientific leadership and mentoring. He is a good supervisor and mentor both to his direct reports and also to other more junior staff. Chris is an excellent team player and contributes across the board at all levels. He has first class communication skills that enable him to effectively get the message across with ease. Chris Haskell’s easygoing manner great personality and leadership skills mark him as a prized individual that any organization could count itself lucky to have.

received.text: I worked with Alex and his staff at Berlex from 2000-2007.  As with many research organizations, the laboratory staff was constantly requiring room modifications and upgrades, as well as ordering equipment that required integration into the labs.  Alex and his team were right on top of these projects, providing excellent service.  His group maintained the overall equipment and environment with the highest regard for safety, efficiency, and dependability.  Alex would be an asset to any organization.

I worked with John Parkinson for seven years at Berlex Biosciences as a colleague in the Department of Immunology, and then later at Bayer Healthcare.  John is a gifted leader, able to get the most out of a team. John also has a keen analytical ability.  He can take a complex problem, break it down into its component parts and determine the critical path activities for solution.  What made it most enjoyable to work with John was that he is a scientist always striving to understand the core mechanisms involved in disease pathology.  John has a drive to get the job done, and I hope to be able to work with him again.

items: Beneficial Role of the GPR30 Agonist G-1 in an Animal Model of Multiple Sclerosis.
